# Chapter 5: The primordial density perturbation

The **curvature perturbation is conserved on superhorizon scales** provided that the pressure of the cosmic fluid depends only on its energy density.

### Notation and conventions

$R$: comoving radius, also denoted $1/k \equiv k^{-1}$
$aR$: true (proper) radius, also denoted $a/k$
$H$: horizon size in natural units ($cH$ in regular units)

$k \ll aH$ $\left(R \gg 1/aH\right)$: long wavelengths; **super**horizon
$k \gg aH$ $\left(R \ll 1/aH\right)$: short wavelengths; **sub**horizon

## 5.1 A first look at the primordial perturbations

### 5.1.1 Epoch of horizon entry

In natural units, the horizon size is $H^{-1}$. In a universe dominated by matter or radiation, $H^{-1} \sim$ the particle horizon.

**Things will not collapse until within horizon**
* **Large scales $(R \gtrsim 10\,\mathrm{Mpc})$:** horizon entry very late, no time to collapse. Observations: no gravitationally bound objects of this size found.
> These regions are actually of great interest, because their stochastic properties provide a direct window into the very early Universe. They are observed more or less directly through their effect on the CMB, right up to the scale $R = \eta_0 \simeq 14 \,\mathrm{Gpc}$ which corresponds to the whole observable universe.
* This seems to imply that we can’t deduce anything about $R > \eta_0$, even statistically. I suppose because everything outside would’ve exited the horizon prior to the last 60 $e$-folds. And given that the universe is inflating again, the comoving horizon is shrinking again.
* **Small scales:** the smallest scale of cosmological interest would’ve entered the horizon after BBN $(T_\text{BBN} \sim 1\,\mathrm{MeV})$, so the run-up to BBN is a good time to look at “initial conditions” of the perturbations

### 5.1.2 Primordial density perturbations

Think of the perturbations (at a scale $R$) as departures from the average density _over all space_ $\rho_a(t)$:
\begin{equation}
\rho_a (R,\mathbf{x},t) = \rho_a (t) + \delta\rho_a(R,\mathbf{x},t),
\end{equation} where $a \in \{\nu, \gamma, b, c\}$ represents the different species contributing to the total density.

### 5.1.3 Main features of the primordial power spectrum

1. Adiabatic
2. Gaussian
3. Scale invariant

### 5.1.4 Other types of primordial perturbation

Tensor perturbations (gravity waves), magnetic fields, cosmic strings or other topological defects. None have been found to date.

## 5.2 Cosmological perturbations

### 5.2.1 Defining the perturbation

With perturbations, cannot find coordinates with preferred slicing and threading; need to choose a **gauge**.

Perturbations in:
1. Density $\delta\rho$
2. Velocity of cosmic fluid $v_i$: peculiar velocity
3. Metric perturbations
4. Photon distribution function $f(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{p},t) = f_\mathbf{p}(\mathbf{x},t)$: CMB anisotropy

Different perturbations are not independent: set of **coupled PDEs**. Only one initial condition to solve the set: **primodial curvature perturbation** $\zeta(\mathbf{x})$.

### 5.2.2 Smoothing

Smoothing means that we assume universe is smooth (homogeneous) **above** a certain size; dropping of Fourier modes $k < 1/R$.

Not all fields can be smoothed. Used only for metric perturbations, energy–momentum tensor, and (sometimes) scalar fields.

## 5.3 The evolution of cosmological perturbations

### 5.3.1 Cosmological perturbation theory

$\left| \delta(\mathbf{x}) \right| \equiv \left| \delta\rho(\mathbf{x})/\rho \right| \ll 1$

### 5.3.2 Separate universe assumption

During super-horizon era $(k \ll aH)$, universe is assumed smooth on a comoving scale $k^{-1}$, the biggest relevant comoving distance scale (and larger). Implies local homogeneity and isotropy, so each point evolves like some unperturbed universe throughout the super-horizon regime.

> In other words, the whole Universe can be regarded as a collection of unperturbed separate universes.

**I don’t really understand this section at all!** Presumably, this is the reason why super-horizon modes don’t do anything until they re-enter the horizon.

### 5.3.3 Strategy for this book

Linear perturbation theory. Good until late times, or non-Gaußianities.

## 5.4 Primordial curvature perturbations

$\zeta(\mathbf{x})$: **the primordial curvature perturbation**

After smoothing on the shortest cosmological scale, $\zeta(\mathbf{x})$ is constant in time (but not space) while that scale approaches horizon entry.

> This constant value determines the total energy density perturbation…, and it provides the main (possibly the sole) initial condition for the subsequent evolution of all perturbations. As a result **it is directly accessible to observations.**

### 5.4.1 Definition

Assuming a gauge where the threads are comoving and the slices have uniform energy density, the spatial metric $g_{ij} = a^2(\mathbf{x},t) \gamma_{ij}(\mathbf{x})$,
\begin{equation}
a(\mathbf{x},t) = a(t) e^{\zeta(\mathbf{x},t)}, \quad \gamma_{ij}(\mathbf{x}) = \left(Ie^{2h}\right)_{ij},
\end{equation} where $h$ defines at first order the _primordial tensor perturbation_. If $h$ is negligible, then $\zeta$ **alone determines the curvature perturbation**.

Since $t$ is the coordinate time labeling the slices, each slice has the same $a(t)$, and the curvature perturbation $\zeta(\mathbf{x})$ is just
\begin{equation}
\zeta = \delta(\log a).
\end{equation}

### 5.4.2 Conservation

The infintesimal volume element $\mathcal{V}$, as seen by a comoving observer:
\begin{align}
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t} \log \mathcal{V} &= \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t} \log (a^3(\mathbf{x},t)) \\
\frac{1}{\mathcal{V}} \frac{\mathrm{d}\mathcal{V}}{\mathrm{d}t} &= \frac{3}{a} \frac{\mathrm{d} a(\mathbf{x},t)}{\mathrm{d}t}.
\end{align}

The continuity equation in an FLRW universe is
\begin{align}
\dot{\rho} &= -3H\big(\rho + P\big) \\
\dot{\rho}(t) &= -3 \frac{\dot{a}(\mathbf{x},t)}{a(\mathbf{x},t)} \big[\rho(t) + P(\mathbf{x},t)\big] \\
&= -3 \left[\frac{\dot{a}(t)}{a(t)} + \dot{\zeta}(\mathbf{x},t) \right] \big[\rho(t) + P(\mathbf{x},t)\big].
\end{align} **N.B.:** $\rho(t)$ has no spatial dependence because each slice has uniform energy density.

> Now suppose that during some era $P$ is a unique function of $\rho$, the same throughout spacetime:
\begin{equation}
P = P(\rho).
\end{equation} Then the spatial dependence of $P$ also vanishes, making $\dot{\zeta}$ independent of position. Without loss of generality, we choose the background scale factor so that $\dot{\zeta}$ vanishes.

\begin{equation}
\dot{\zeta} = 0 \quad\Leftrightarrow\quad \zeta = \text{constant},
\end{equation} or, $\zeta$ **is conserved**. This is satisfied for basically all epochs of the universe:
* Radiation-dominated: $P = \rho/3$
* Matter-dominated: $P \equiv 0$
* $\Lambda$-dominated: $P = -\rho$
* or **any combination of the above**

**N.B.:** We haven’t specified any theory of gravity or used perturbation theory – only the **adiabatic condition** $P = P(\rho)$.

### 5.4.3 The $\delta N$ formula

Pick some other slicing. The perturbation in the local number of Hubble times between two generic slices is
\begin{equation}
\delta N_{12}(\mathbf{x}) = \delta \int_{t_1}^{t_2} H \,\mathrm{d}t = \delta \int_{t_1}^{t_2} \frac{\dot{a}}{a} \mathrm{d}t = \psi(\mathbf{x},t_2) - \psi(\mathbf{x},t_1).
\end{equation}

**Flat slicing:** $\psi \equiv 0$

**The $\delta N$ formula:** Let $N(\mathbf{x},t)$ be the local number of Hubble times starting from a fixed flat slice $\big(\psi(\mathbf{x},t_1) = 0\big)$ and ending on a uniform-density slice labeled by time $t$. Then

\begin{equation}
\zeta(\mathbf{x},t) = \delta N(\mathbf{x},t).
\end{equation}

## 5.5 Linear density perturbations

Need to define $\zeta$ using a slicing that isn’t uniform density (which has no density perturbations – $\zeta$ is the _curvature_ perturbation).

### 5.5.1 Gauge transformation

For a scalar quantity $f$ defined independent of the coordinates, to first order,
\begin{equation}
\overset{\sim}{\delta f}(\mathbf{x},\tilde{t}) - \delta{f}(\mathbf{x},t) = -\dot{f}(t) \,\delta t(\mathbf{x},t),
\end{equation} where $\tilde{}$ indicates a quantity in the new gauge.
* $\rho$, $P$, and $n$ (number density) fall under this category

For a 4-vector or 4-tensor quantity, which _does_ depend on the coordinates, to first order,
\begin{equation}
\overset{\sim}{\delta B}_{\mu\nu} - \delta B_{\mu\nu} = -B_{\alpha\nu} \partial_\mu \delta x^\alpha - B_{\mu\alpha} \partial_\nu \delta x^\alpha - \delta x^\lambda \partial_\lambda B_{\mu\nu}.
\end{equation}

### 5.5.2 Primordial density perturbations

Starting from a uniform-density slice at time $t$, we get the curvature perturbation on a generic slice at time $\tilde{t}$ using the two $\delta N$ equations in Section 5.4.3:
\begin{align}
\psi(\mathbf{x},\tilde{t}) &= \zeta(\mathbf{x},t) \\
&= \zeta(\mathbf{x}, \tilde{t} - \delta t) \\
&= \zeta(\mathbf{x},\tilde{t}) - H \,\delta t
\end{align} to first order, where $\delta t = t_2 - t_1$.

The density perturbation is a scalar quantity, so
\begin{equation}
\overset{\sim}{\delta\rho}(\mathbf{x},\tilde{t}) = -\dot{\rho}(t) \,\delta t(\mathbf{x},t)
\end{equation} (recalling that $\delta\rho(\mathbf{x},t) \equiv 0$ on a uniform-density slice). Dropping all $\tilde{}$ and references to coordinates, the **gauge invariant definition** of $\zeta$ is
\begin{align}
\zeta &= \psi - H \frac{\delta\rho}{\dot{\rho}} \\
&= \psi + \frac{1}{3} \frac{\delta\rho}{\rho+P}
\end{align} (via the continuity equation – see Section 5.4.2). On a flat slicing,
\begin{equation}
\zeta = -H \frac{\delta\rho}{\dot{\rho}} = \frac{1}{3} \frac{\delta\rho}{\rho+P}.
\end{equation}

The adiabatic condition + the continuity equation implies
\begin{equation}
\frac{1}{3} \delta_b = \frac{1}{3} \delta_c = \frac{1}{4} \delta_\gamma = \frac{1}{4} \delta_\nu
\end{equation} where $\delta_a \equiv \delta\rho_a/\rho_a$ are the density contrasts.
